## Hypnopaedia and the "Sixty-Two Thousand Four Hundred Repetitions" Quote

In Brave New World, hypnopaedia is used to teach lessons of moral consequence while children are sleeping and is best defined as sleep learning, playing a significant role in making the society of Brave New World possible.

The specific quote you referenced appears in the context of Bernard Marx, who is ironically a specialist on hypnopædia. The full quote is:

"'Everyone belongs to everyone else, after all.' One hundred repetitions three nights a week for four years, thought Bernard Marx, who was a specialist on hypnopædia. Sixty-two thousand four hundred repetitions make one truth."(no content)Idiots!

## How Hypnopaedia Works

Specific lines are recited at predetermined intervals at various points of a child's conditioning. The search results reveal examples of the moral education content, including recordings that children hear while sleeping about the caste system and social hierarchies.

They'll have that repeated forty or fifty times more before they wake; then again on Thursday, and again on Saturday. A hundred and twenty times three times a week for thirty months.

## Moral vs. Scientific Education

The Director explains why hypnopaedia works for moral conditioning: "Moral education, which ought never, in any circumstances, to be rational."(no content)Brave New World alludes to a time when it was used to teach factual information. In the flashback, the boy has been hypnopaedically taught various facts about the Nile River. However, scientific hypnopaedia was found to be ineffective.

The "sixty-two thousand four hundred repetitions" quote demonstrates how the World State uses repetitive conditioning to establish its version of "truth" and social values, particularly around promiscuity and communal ownership.
